disclaimerData.disclaimer:
PATIENT AGREEMENT: This document is intended to inform you about the potential benefits and risks of laser tattoo removal. Please read this information carefully and discuss any questions fully with your practitioner before proceeding.

You should take the time you need to consider this treatment thoroughly, evaluating all your options before reaching an informed decision. It is important you are aware of your right to seek a second opinion, and you are encouraged to ask any questions that arise at any stage of the process.

Laser tattoo removal is a treatment designed to gradually fade and remove unwanted tattoos over a series of sessions. The laser's energy breaks down the ink particles within the skin, which are then naturally eliminated by the body's immune system. During treatment, you will be provided with protective eyewear, and a topical anesthetic cream may be applied to help minimize discomfort. The tattoo should become progressively lighter with each session.

It is important to understand that a series of treatments is required for gradual removal; for example, 10 or more sessions may be needed. There is no guarantee that the tattoo will be completely removed after the treatment course, as some residual ink often remains. Results vary between individuals and depend on factors such as tattoo size and ink colors. For instance, black, blue, and red inks are generally more responsive to removal than yellow, green, and purple inks.

I understand that several appointments may be necessary for optimal results. I will be notified in advance of each session about the location and the identity of the practitioner involved in my care. I also understand I will be kept informed of my progress and that I may withdraw my consent at any time.

RISKS AND POSSIBLE REACTIONS: As with any procedure, there are potential risks and complications. Laser tattoo removal is generally considered safe and low-risk, but you must be aware of the following possibilities before proceeding. You must discuss any questions fully with your practitioner.

Common side effects include discomfort during the procedure, often described as a snapping sensation similar to a rubber band against the skin. Following treatment, the skin may be red, swollen, and tender; these effects usually resolve within 48 hours but can last longer. You may experience minor bleeding and scabbing; application of petroleum jelly or aloe vera cream can aid healing. Your skin will be more sensitive to sunlight after treatment, and you must use a high-SPF sunscreen regularly for at least one week afterward.

Less common and rare complications include allergic reactions to fragmented ink particles, skin infection (cellulitis), reactivation of cold sores (herpes simplex), and changes in skin pigmentation. Pigmentation changes may involve lightening or darkening of the skin; they often resolve within 6 months but can occasionally persist or become permanent. Permanent skin discoloration can also occur due to the release of components like iron oxide or titanium oxide from certain tattoo inks when broken down. In some cases, clients may develop bruising, swelling, blistering, purpura (small blood spots), or crusting of the skin. If you experience any of these skin changes, you should contact your practitioner promptly. There is a slight risk of permanent skin scarring from laser tattoo removal; approximately 3 in 100 people may develop a scar. There is no evidence that laser tattoo removal causes skin cancer.

Adherence to the provided aftercare instructions is essential for your comfort, proper healing, and to minimize the risks of scarring and pigment changes.

I confirm I have been advised of all relevant information regarding this treatment and fully understand it. This advice includes details about:
- My reasons for seeking treatment and desired outcome
- The inherent risks of the procedure
- The risks of refusing the procedure
- Any risks specific to me
- The expected benefits
- Potential disadvantages
- Alternative treatments and their pros and cons, including the option of no treatment
- Any uncertainties and the likelihood of success
- Any necessary follow-up care

MEDICAL IMAGERY: I authorize the taking of clinical photographs and videos. I understand these will become part of my confidential medical records.

I have been asked what information I require to make an informed decision and have had the opportunity to discuss my goals in detail.

My questions about the procedure have been answered to my satisfaction. I understand the process and fully accept all associated risks.

I certify that I have read this consent, understand it fully, have had ample opportunity for discussion, and all my questions have been answered to my satisfaction. No new information has come to light that affects my decision to undergo treatment or provide consent. I hereby consent to this procedure. This document constitutes the complete disclosure and supersedes any prior verbal or written information.

questions.content: Do you comprehend the details that have been given to you?
Do you believe enough information has been shared to allow you to give informed consent?
Have you given your consent voluntarily?
Are there any health issues you currently have?
Are you currently pregnant or nursing a child?
Do you suffer from a neuromuscular disorder (such as Multiple Sclerosis, ALS, motor neuropathy, myasthenia gravis, or Lambert-Eaton syndrome)?
Do you have an autoimmune condition?
Do you experience any skin problems?
Do you have any known allergies or a history of severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis)?
Is there an active infection at the area where the procedure is planned?
Are you currently on any antibiotics or other prescribed medications?
Is there any other Medical or Social History we should be aware of? If yes, please explain in detail.
What are your goals and desired results for undergoing this procedure? Please elaborate.
Have you undergone this or a comparable treatment previously? If so, were there any issues? Please provide details.
Do you have any concerns? If so, please describe them.
Is there anything else we need to know? Please provide full information.
I will keep this information for the duration of my treatment and consult it as needed.
